title: What Are Points and Miles?
excerpt: Understand the difference between credit card points, airline miles, and hotel currencies so you can choose the right ones for your goals.
seoTitle: What Are Travel Points and Miles? | Miles Go Round
seoDescription: A beginner-friendly walkthrough of how travel rewards currencies work across banks, airlines, and hotels.

sections.heading: Points vs. miles
body: Banks issue flexible points that can move to multiple airlines or hotels, while miles are tied to one loyalty program.
Knowing which currency you have matters because transfer partners and redemption tools vary by issuer.

sections.heading: How they are earned
body: Credit card spend, welcome bonuses, and limited-time offers are the primary ways to earn both points and miles.
Some programs also award miles through shopping portals, dining programs, and travel partners.

sections.heading: Why they hold value
body: Redemption rates often beat cash prices when you target premium cabins or aspirational hotels.
Understanding the currency lets you match the right program to the trip you want to book.

title: Earning Points: The Basics
excerpt: Set up your wallet so everyday spend builds balances that are easy to move and redeem.

sections.heading: Start with a transferable currency
body: Cards that earn flexible bank points give you multiple airline and hotel transfer partners to choose from.
This flexibility protects you when a single program devalues or when a specific route lacks award space.

sections.heading: Use category bonuses
body: Groceries, dining, and travel often earn higher multipliers. Align your cards to maximize those categories.
Track which card to use where with a simple note in your wallet or a phone lock screen wallpaper.

sections.heading: Stack limited-time offers
body: Transfer bonuses and shopping portal promos can add 10â€“30% more value to the same purchase.
Check for targeted offers before big expenses and stack them with category bonuses when possible.

title: Redeeming Points With a Plan
excerpt: Match the right currency to the trip you want, and you will avoid wasting hard-earned points.
seoDescription: A simple framework to choose the best redemption for flights and hotels without overthinking charts.

sections.heading: Define the goal first
body: Pick a destination, cabin, and date range. The clearer your goal, the easier it is to pick the best loyalty program.
Goals also help you decide whether to transfer points, book through a portal, or pay cash.

sections.heading: Check partners before you transfer
body: Many airlines share alliances, letting you book one carrier with another's miles. Verify award space before moving points.
Look for sweet spots where a partner charges fewer miles than the operating airline for the same seat.

sections.heading: Value your points
body: Compare the cash fare to the miles required. If the cents-per-point value is low, save miles for a better opportunity.
Remember to factor in fees, surcharges, and whether the ticket earns elite-qualifying credit.

title: Glossary: Common Points & Miles Terms
excerpt: A quick reference for jargon like transfer partner, dynamic pricing, and award chart.
seoTitle: Points & Miles Glossary | Miles Go Round

sections.heading: Transfer partner
body: An airline or hotel program that accepts points from a bank currency, usually at a 1:1 ratio.
Partners expand your options beyond the bank's own travel portal.

sections.heading: Dynamic pricing
body: A system where award prices rise and fall with demand instead of following a fixed chart.
During off-peak dates, dynamic programs can offer great value; peak travel can be expensive.

sections.heading: Award chart
body: A published table that shows how many miles you need for specific regions, cabins, or dates.
Charts make it easier to spot sweet spots and to know whether a redemption is fair.
